name: Tea (Cha)
uses: Meditation aid - enhances alertness during zazen
Tea ceremony (Chanoyu) - Way of Tea spiritual practice
Daily monastic practice - consumed throughout day in temples
L-theanine + caffeine = calm focus perfect for meditation
sacredSignificance: Tea and Zen are 'one taste' (Cha Zen Ichimi). Bodhidharma legend: his eyelids became first tea plants to aid meditation. Essential to Zen Buddhist practice.
preparationMethods: Matcha: whisk powder in hot water (70-80°C) until frothy
Gongfu cha: multiple short steeps in small teapot
Temple style: large pot of light green tea served communally

buddhist.usage: Central to Zen/Chan practice. Japanese tea ceremony (Chado) is spiritual discipline. Every Zen temple has tea practice.
buddhist.significance: Symbolizes mindfulness, impermanence, simplicity. Meditation and tea inseparable.

chinese.usage: Chan Buddhist temples, Gongfu tea ceremony
chinese.significance: Aid to meditation, represents middle way between sleep and agitation

tibetan.usage: Butter tea (po cha) with salt and yak butter
tibetan.significance: Daily staple in monasteries, warming and energizing
